page.syntax: Position as N = AT(C search_string,C string[,N occurrence])

argument.name: string
argument.description: The character string to examine for occurrences of search_string.

argument.name: occurrence
argument.description: Optional. Default = 1. The integer number specifying which occurrence to return. -1 Specifies the last occurrence of the search_string. If omitted, the first occurrence of the search_string will be returned.

page.description: Returns the position where one character string is found in another.
page.discussion: AT() returns a position integer indicating where the n th occurrence of the search string begins in the string. If the search_string is not found, AT() returns 0. n is specified through the Number argument. Search is case-sensitive. See ATC() for a case-insensitive version of this function. Limitations: The search string argument is case sensitive.
page.example: at(",", CITYSTZIP, 1) -> 10, if CITYSTZIP contains "Cambridge, MA02139" at("Tim", FIRSTNAME, 1) -> 0, if FIRSTNAME contains "Fred"

section.description: Assume that a table contains the city, state, and zip code all in one field (e.g., "Cambridge, MA02139"). Suppose you want to print a report displaying the city, state, and zip code in three separate columns. You can define three calculated fields called CITY, STATE, and ZIP, and use the AT() and SUBSTR()functions to locate, and then the SUBSTR() function to extract, the information from the original CITYSTZIP field.
